questions.text: Inflation during laparoscopy is done with the help of which instrument?
questions.solution:
There are two fundamental ways to access the abdomen laparoscopically:

  1. the open technique (Hasson's or modifed Hasson's)
  2. the closed technique (Veress needle and/or visual entry trocar).

Veress needle is used for creating initial pneumoperitoneum so that the trocar can enter safely and the distance of the abdominal wall from the abdominal viscera should increase.

Veress needle consists of an outer cannula with a beveled needlepoint for cutting through tissues. Inside the cannula is an inner stylet, which is loaded with a spring that "springs forward" in response to the sudden decrease in pressure encountered upon crossing the abdominal wall and entering the peritoneal cavity. The lateral hole on this stylet enables CO2 gas to be delivered intra-abdominally.

For the patient with scars from previous abdominal surgery, the safest technique is an open approach at Palmer's point, 3 cm below the left subcostal margin in the mid-clavicular line. Adequate lighting and good assistance with retraction are essential

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy 3 days ago and had abdominal pain in the postoperative period and the patient had tachycardia. WBC count is 11000 cells/mm3, on USG evaluation done shows a collection 5x5 cm in right hypochondrium what is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Patients who develop jaundice in the postoperative period need urgent investigation as it can be attributed to bile duct injury

Treatment:

Initially resuscitation and administration of appropriate antibiotics should be done

Following which USG will demonstrate whether there is intra- or extrahepatic ductal dilatation or biliary leak etc.

Usg guided T-tube/pigtail catheter is inserted and the duct closed around it, the long limb is brought out on the right side and bile is allowed to drain externally.

After 2 weeks, leak usually stops, if leak not stopped, next step is ERCP, it is both diagnostic and therapeutic, so if ERCP shows bile duct injury, stenting and sphincterotomy can be done in the same sitting.

Other investigations in bile duct injury:

HIDA scan (can identify leak), MRCP (for bile duct stricture)

Investigation which is of no use is CECT abdomen

Strasberg classification of bile duct injuries:

(a) Bile leak from the cystic duct stump or minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa.

(b) An occluded right posterior sectoral duct.

(c) A bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.

(d) A bile leak from the main bile duct without any major tissue loss.

  • E1, transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2 cm from the hilus.
  • E2, transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2 cm from the hilus.
  • E3, stricture of the hilus with the right and left ducts in communication.
  • E4, stricture of the hilus with separation of the right and left hepatic ducts.
  • E5, stricture involving the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain and multiple cholelithiasis with CBD diameter 12mm. Serum Bilirubin 0.8. Alkaline phosphatase is around 380. GGT is 5 times normal. What will be the next step of management
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario pt presents with abdominal pain, elevated ALP, GGT with multiple cholelithiasis with CBD, hence MRCP is preferred over ERCP to confirm CBD stones.

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive modality that provides excellent images of the gallbladder and biliary system, it's a T2 weighted MRI with bile itself acting as contrast

Without the potential complications of the ERCP and PTC, they can demonstrate ductal abnormalities, including obstruction/stricture, stones and tumours.

Treatment includes ERCP along with sphincterotomy and stone removal.

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, projectional images demonstrating stones and hilar obstruction.

choices.text: Follow up after 6 months and thereafter 2 years

questions.text: A female patient with lump present in right breast upper outer quadrant 4cm x 3cm, axillary lymph node is negative, mammography reveals BIRADS 4; patient underwent breast conservative surgery (BCS), final HPE report reveals DCIS with high grade, what will be done next in management?
questions.solution:
Tumor of 4*3 cm with no node involvement - T2N0, patient underwent BCS (breast conservative surgery)

BCS includes:

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node sentinel lymph node biopsy
  3. Radiotherapy to remaining breast
  4. Follow up

Based on the biopsy report - chemotherapy and hormone therapy done based on report

In this case, HPE shows high grade DCIS

The next best step in management would be adjuvant radiotherapy according to the Van Nuys prognostic index.

questions.text: Size of Green colour Cannula is?
questions.solution:
Green colored IV cannula:

Specifications of this cannula: 18 gauge, external diameter of 1.3mm, length of : 32\45mm with a flow rate of 90ml/min, most commonly used in trauma and quick blood transfusions

  • In trauma: minimum 2 green cannula is used
  • Cannulas used when maximum and faster infusion required: orange (14G) and grey (16G) cannulas.
  • Fluid infused: crystalloids (normal saline) of 1litre given immediately

Reference: https://www.neotecmedical.com/safety-i-v-cannula-with-injection-v.

questions.text: Identify the urinary Crystal shown below;
questions.solution:
• Calcium oxalate stones

This is the most common type of stone, envelop or bipyramidal shaped, constituting 60-85% of all stones. Hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria and hypocitraturia are known metabolic abnormalities that can predispose to its formation.

  • Calcium phosphate stones

Common forms seen are apatite and brushite stones. Apatite is seen with infection and brushite stones are usually seen with distal RTA.

  • Uric acid stones

Multifaceted, Hyperuricosuria promotes the formation of both calcium oxalate and uric acid stones.

  • Staghorn calculi

These are struvite and apatite stones. Coffin lid shaped. They form as a result of urease-producing bacterial infections, such as those caused by Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia or Enterobacter. Alkalinisation of urine takes place as urease hydrolyses urea to carbon dioxide and ammonium.

  • Cystine stones

Benzene shaped, Cystine stones are very hard stones as a result of disulphide bonds and do not fragment with SWL.

questions.text: Identify the Hernia, in 5 years child with intermittent abdominal pain, image shown below?
questions.solution:
• The given xray shows thoracic hernia of abdominal contents through defect in diaphragm suggesting a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Several genes share roles in diaphragmatic, pulmonary, cardiac and foregut development; consequently, congenital diaphragmatic hernias are associated with lung hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac defects and gastroesophageal reflux, with half having additional anomalies.
  • A left posterolateral or Bochdalek defect - most common content is stomach
  • Less commonly a ventral right anteromedial or Morgagni defect - most common content is transverse colon

Diagnosis:

  • The diagnosis is usually made antenatally. A prognosis based on an observed-to-expected lung-head ratio (ultrasound), total fetal lung volume (magnetic resonance imaging) and whether or not the fetal liver is in the chest informs counselling.

questions.text: Most common cause for readmission after day care surgery
questions.solution:
Day care surgery:

  • Discharge in 12hrs of admission
  • Pt should be going home with no vomiting, no pain, no altered BP
  • Duration of surgery should be < 2hrs
  • Pt should be able to reach the hospital within 1hr

The most common cause for readmission in day care surgery is nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Angle between skin and needle when performing intermittent sutures?
questions.solution:
Interrupted sutures. Interrupted sutures require the needle to be inserted at right angles to the incision and then to pass through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at right angles.

The edge of the wound should correspond to the thickness of the tissue being sutured (x). Each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart (2x).

Continuous sutures. For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Mattress sutures. Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal and tend to be used to produce either eversion or inversion of a wound edge

Subcuticular suture. This technique is used in skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

questions.text: In a 3-year-old child, the mother notices a huge abdominal swelling with Ballot-ability. H/O Hematuria which was resolved in 2 days. O/E ballot-able abdominal swelling is the only significant finding. what all the investigations you will do?
questions.solution:
The c/f of a 3 yr old child with ballotable mass h/o hematuria suggests the child with Wilms tumor.

The tumour has mixed elements derived from the embryonic nephrogenic tissue, namely blastemal or undifferentiated tissue, epithelial tubules and stroma.

The typical presentation is a child aged between 1 and 4 years of either gender with a large, palpable abdominal mass that may cross the midline. It may also be associated with haematuria, hypertension, fever and weight loss. Pain is relatively uncommon. Hematuria is a bad prognostic factor of wilms tumor.

Investigation:

CECT or MRI is necessary to stage the disease.

The tumours usually infiltrate the kidneys and normal renal parenchyma is compressed at the periphery around the tumour (claw sign). A CT of the chest should be obtained as the lung is the most common site of distant metastasis.

It is important to know radiological features of neuroblastoma while comparing it with wilms tumor:

  1. Crosses midline
  2. Calcification present
  3. Drooping lily sign on IVP

PET CT should be done to find out distant metastasis.

Treatment:

Current treatment is nephrectomy with pre- or postoperative chemotherapy

2 protocol:

  • SIOP protocol: preoperative chemotherapy → shrink the tumor → staging → surgery
  • NWTSG protocol: surgery → chemotherapy

Both have good prognosis, but SIOP is preferred in

  1. Bilateral Wilma tumor
  2. Patient with single kidney developing Wilms tumor
  3. Altered renal function test

questions.text: A patient presents with renal swelling with thickened walls and septations of Bosniak Type 3 as shown in image
questions.solution:
The radiological image shows muscle element, blood vessels and fat suggesting it is angiomyolipoma

Angiomyolipoma comes under type 3 Bosnian cyst

Complication of angiomyolipoma:

Rupture in the retroperitoneum - WUNDERLICH SYNDROME

IOC: CECT abdomen

Management: partial subcapsular nephrectomy

Bosniak Classification of Cystic Renal Masses:

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4341374/

https://pubs.rsna.org/doi/full/10.1148/rg.2021200160

choices.text: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.text: A boy with perineal injury came to the emergency department on examination blood present at meatus has not passed urine. Bladder not full. The Next step of management in this scenario will be?
questions.solution:
The given nature of injury with blood present at meatus and not passing urine suggest it is a bulbar urethra injury and patient has not passed urine would depict the bladder is not full moreover pt. should be discouraged to pass the urine.

Clinical features:

The signs of a ruptured bulbar urethra are perineal bruising and haematoma, typically with a butterfly distribution. There is usually bleeding from the urethral meatus and retention of urine.

Investigations include a retrograde urethrogram (RGU)

Treatment:

  • Initially analgesia and antibiotics should be
  • should be discouraged to pass the urine.
  • As in the given case the bladder is not palpable the best option would be to wait for the bladder and urge to urinate.
  • Delayed anastomotic urethroplasty is performed after 3 months with excellent success rates.

(a) Percutaneous puncture of the bladder with passage of a guidewire into the bladder followed by dilatation of the track over the guidewire (b), thereby allowing placement of a catheter into the bladder (c).

questions.text: Best investigation to localize parathyroid tissue?
questions.solution:
Nuclear medicine-based studies (sestamibi scanning)

Regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands.

It has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasonography, it may image glands in ectopic positions better.

Sestamibi accumulates in mitochondria and therefore washes out at differential rates depending on the number of mitochondria within individual tissues.

Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content.

Hurthle cell adenoma can also mimic a parathyroid gland, to differentiate it Tc99m subsctraction sestamibi scan

Image of sestamibi scan.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless hard enlargement of the testis. LDH values are increased. Next best step is?
questions.solution:
The c/f and the raised AFP levels are suggestive of a testicular tumor, probably a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) and the next best step in management is high inguinal orchidectomy.

Painless testicular enlargement:

  1. Testicular Tumor
  2. Syphilis

Testicular tumors are of:

  1. Seminoma: most common type, with normal alpha fetoprotein and HCG, and mild elevation of LDH
  2. Non seminomatous: very high levels of alpha fetoprotein and HCG

Transcrotal biopsy is contraindicated as it causes dissemination of tumor cells

Next step in case of testicular tumor - chevassu's manuvere where testis is delivered by high inguinal orchidectomy

choices.text: To categorise the number of injuries

questions.solution:
Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It aims to identify/sort out according to severity, those patients who will benefit the most by being treated the earliest, ensuring 'the greatest good for the greatest number'.

Triage tag

questions.text:
COVID 19 positive patient requiring hospitalization can be planned for surgery after
How many weeks?
questions.solution:
If a patients tests positive for covid-19, elective surgical procedures should be delayed until the patient is no longer infectious and has demonstrated recovery from COVID-19.

The timing of elective surgery after recovery from COVID-19 uses both symptom- and severity-based categories.

  • Four weeks for an asymptomatic patient or recovery from only mild, non-respiratory symptoms.
  • Six weeks for a symptomatic patient (e.g., cough, dyspnea) who did not require hospitalization.
  • Eight to 10 weeks for a symptomatic patient who is diabetic, immunocompromised, or hospitalized.
  • Twelve weeks for a patient who was admitted to an intensive care unit due to COVID-19 infection

Key aspects in COVID-19 surgical patient management

  • All suspected or infected patients must be managed with the maximum attention.
  • All personnel in contact with the patient must wear PPE.
  • Transfers must be protected.
  • Infected patients must be moved as little as possible through the hospital.
  • Transfer routes must be precisely planned and be as short as possible.
  • The COVID operating area should be in a dedicated and possibly separate area.
  • COVID operating room must be dedicated and as close as possible to the entrance of the theater block.
  • Disposable material should be preferred.
  • Minimal material should be used for each intervention.
  • Transport personnel should be the same from transport origin to destination.
  • Once the patient has entered, the OR doors must be closed.
  • Operators (i.e., surgeon, anesthetist, nurses, technicians) should enter the OR in a timely manner to minimize exposure to infected patients.
  • Personnel involved in the intervention should not leave the OR during the procedure.
  • High OR air exchange cycles are recommended (> 25 exchanges/h).
  • Clinical documentation must remain outside the OR
  • At the end of each intervention all disposable materials must be disposed of and all surfaces and electromedical devices accurately cleaned and disinfected.
  • PPE must be removed and disposed of outside the OR in dedicated doffing areas ensuring the virus is not transmitted to the healthcare worker.
  • OR and surrounding donning/doffing areas must be sanitized as soon as possible after each procedure.
  • After each procedure, all involved personnel, whenever possible, should shower.
  • Recovery phase after surgery must be done in OR, before transfer to the ward/ICU.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7137852/

https://www.asahq.org/in-the-spotlight/coronavirus-covid-19-information/elective-surgery
